text: SEEMA AZIZ: So I went.

And by then I was
worrying away--
it was easy.
It was easy.
The children were bright.

Every school that we
built was filling up,

and the children were
just doing amazingly well.

Like you said, a lot of
people would come by and say,
why is their writing so good?
Something's wrong here.

The teachers are writing their
copies, and it wasn't true.

And everyone would say,
why are your children's
accents so good?

And anyway, so I went
and surveyed about 25,

30 schools in the
city of Lahore,

and that was another whole eye
opener, the government schools.

Sadly, very sadly,
the state schools
were in very bad condition.

And lots of schools no
drinking water, no toilets.
Children sweeping floors.
Teachers who were missing.

No furniture, labs and
libraries were non-existent.
No lights, no fans very often.

So I agreed to take on
10 government schools.
It was a real struggle.

The unions wanted
us out, whatever.
SPEAKER: The teachers' unions.
SEEMA AZIZ: The teachers.

There were 11 teachers
unions, and they just

went, you foreign
agent, get out of here.

SPEAKER: Foreign agent, is
that what they call you?
SEEMA AZIZ: Much worst, but yes.

So the unions didn't-- they
thought that you know somebody

has come to take over
what was their domain,

and they were doing
a pretty bad job.

But anyway so as we
adopted those schools

and committed to put in labs
and libraries, fans and lights,

and furniture,
and whatever else,
we started with the 10 schools.

And then of course, the unions
they're saying, get out,
get out of our schools.
So I made a policy of--

realized that nobody
would want us,

so I made a policy
of non-confrontation
and non-criticism.

And realized that the change
that we've managed to make over

the years was through
example, and I've

understood that it's not by
lecturing and not by training.

So we quietly started
doing the work,

you know, doing what we
wanted to do in the way
that we wanted to do.

And that was the
message, spoken policy

that we'll be role models,
and we will never give anyone
an opportunity to throw us out.
And so we continued.

We managed to turn those
schools around within a year.

Enrolments doubled,
results started changing.
